segment.source: Interactive logon Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL (Windows 10)
segment.target: Interactive logon Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Interactive logon Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Interactive logon Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL security policy setting.

segment.source: Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL
segment.target: Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL security policy setting.

segment.source: This security setting determines whether pressing CTRL+ALT+DEL is required before a user can log on.
segment.target: This security setting determines whether pressing CTRL+ALT+DEL is required before a user can log on.

segment.source: If this policy setting is enabled on a device, a user is not required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL to log on.
segment.target: If this policy setting is enabled on a device, a user is not required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL to log on.

segment.source: Not having to press CTRL+ALT+DEL leaves users susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept the users' passwords.
segment.target: Not having to press CTRL+ALT+DEL leaves users susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept the users' passwords.

segment.source: Requiring CTRL+ALT+DEL before users log on ensures that users are communicating by means of a trusted path when entering their passwords.
segment.target: Requiring CTRL+ALT+DEL before users log on ensures that users are communicating by means of a trusted path when entering their passwords.

segment.source: If this policy is disabled, any user is required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL before logging on to the Windows operating system (unless they are using a smart card for logon).
segment.target: If this policy is disabled, any user is required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL before logging on to the Windows operating system (unless they are using a smart card for logon).

segment.source: Microsoft developed this feature to make it easier for users with certain types of physical impairments to log on to device running the Windows operating system; however, not having to press the CTRL+ALT+DELETE key combination leaves users susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept their passwords.
segment.target: Microsoft developed this feature to make it easier for users with certain types of physical impairments to log on to device running the Windows operating system; however, not having to press the CTRL+ALT+DELETE key combination leaves users susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept their passwords.

segment.source: Requiring CTRL+ALT+DELETE before users log on ensures that users are communicating by means of a trusted path when entering their passwords.
segment.target: Requiring CTRL+ALT+DELETE before users log on ensures that users are communicating by means of a trusted path when entering their passwords.

segment.source: A malicious user might install malware that looks like the standard logon dialog box for the Windows operating system, and capture a user's password.
segment.target: A malicious user might install malware that looks like the standard logon dialog box for the Windows operating system, and capture a user's password.

segment.source: The attacker can then log on to the compromised account with whatever level of user rights that user has.
segment.target: The attacker can then log on to the compromised account with whatever level of user rights that user has.

segment.source: It is advisable to set Disable CTRL+ALT+DEL requirement for logon to Disabled.
segment.target: It is advisable to set Disable CTRL+ALT+DEL requirement for logon to Disabled.

segment.source: Unless they are using a smart card to log on, users will have to simultaneously press three keys before the logon dialog box appears.
segment.target: Unless they are using a smart card to log on, users will have to simultaneously press three keys before the logon dialog box appears.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Beginning with Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista, the CTRL+ALT+DELETE key combination is required to authenticate if this policy is disabled.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista, the CTRL+ALT+DELETE key combination is required to authenticate if this policy is disabled.

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: This setting makes it easier for users with certain types of physical impairments to log on to devices that run the Windows operating system.
segment.target: This setting makes it easier for users with certain types of physical impairments to log on to devices that run the Windows operating system.

segment.source: However, if users are not required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL, they are susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept their passwords.
segment.target: However, if users are not required to press CTRL+ALT+DEL, they are susceptible to attacks that attempt to intercept their passwords.

segment.source: If CTRL+ALT+DEL is required before logon, user passwords are communicated by means of a trusted path.
segment.target: If CTRL+ALT+DEL is required before logon, user passwords are communicated by means of a trusted path.

segment.source: If this setting is enabled, an attacker could install malware that looks like the standard logon dialog box in the Windows operating system, and capture the user's password.
segment.target: If this setting is enabled, an attacker could install malware that looks like the standard logon dialog box in the Windows operating system, and capture the user's password.

segment.source: The attacker would then be able to log on to the compromised account with whatever level of privilege that user has.
segment.target: The attacker would then be able to log on to the compromised account with whatever level of privilege that user has.

segment.source: Disable the Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL setting.
segment.target: Disable the Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL setting.

segment.source: Unless they use a smart card to log on, users must simultaneously press the three keys before the logon dialog box is displayed.
segment.target: Unless they use a smart card to log on, users must simultaneously press the three keys before the logon dialog box is displayed.
